title: 109_s3918
content: The Act titled "9/11 Heroes Health Improvement Act of 2006" provides grants for 9/11-related health care. The "9/11 Heroes Health Improvement Act of 2006" authorizes grants for medical and mental health services for individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks in New York City and at the Pentagon. Eligible entities will receive grants to provide monitoring, tracking, and treatment to those impacted. The "9/11 Heroes Health Improvement Act of 2006" authorizes grants for medical and mental health services for individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks in New York City and at the Pentagon. Eligible entities will receive grants to provide monitoring, analysis, treatment through various organizations such as the Mount Sinai Center for Occupational and Environmental Medicine, New York City Fire Department's Bureau of Health Services, New York City Police Foundation's Project COPE, Police Organization Providing Peer Assistance, and New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene's World Trade Center Health Registry. The "9/11 Heroes Health Improvement Act of 2006" authorizes grants for medical and mental health services for individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks in New York City and at the Pentagon. Eligible entities will receive grants to provide monitoring, tracking, and treatment for responders at the Pentagon, including firefighters, police officers, and paramedics. The "9/11 Heroes Health Improvement Act of 2006" provides grants for medical and mental health services to individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks, including responders at Ground Zero, Fresh Kills, and the Pentagon. Priority for assistance is given to individuals without health insurance coverage and those needing additional care beyond their insurance. The "9/11 Heroes Health Improvement Act of 2006" provides grants for medical and mental health services to individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks. Priority is given to those without sufficient health insurance coverage and individuals in need of additional care. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention must submit a report on fund usage, and $1,914,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. The Secretary may use up to $10,000,000 for staffing and administrative expenses related to implementing this section. Additionally, the Secretary can utilize any funds appropriated to the Department of Health and Human Services or other designated funds for this purpose.
